block.p: Maggie Tai Sakaki Tucker, the daughter of Nancy Tucker of Manhattan and Nanao Sakaki of Izu, Japan, was married last evening to James S. Gwertzman, a son of Marie-Jeanne and Bernard Gwertzman of Riverdale, the Bronx. The Rev. Alma Daniel, an interfaith minister, officiated at the Boathouse in Central Park.

Ms. Tucker, 29, is keeping her name. She ran a dog training service in Tokyo until last month. The bride graduated from Harvard University and is to begin studying in September for a doctorate in animal behavior at the University of Washington. Her father is a poet, whose published volumes include ''Break the Mirror'' (Blackberry, 1996) and ''Let's Eat Stars'' (Blackberry, 1997).

Maggie Tai Sakaki Tucker, the daughter of Nancy Tucker of Manhattan and Nanao Sakaki of Izu, Japan, was married last evening to James S. Gwertzman, a son of Marie-Jeanne and Bernard Gwertzman of Riverdale, the Bronx. The Rev. Alma Daniel, an interfaith minister, officiated at the Boathouse in Central Park.

Ms. Tucker, 29, is keeping her name. She ran a dog training service in Tokyo until last month. The bride graduated from Harvard University and is to begin studying in September for a doctorate in animal behavior at the University of Washington. Her father is a poet, whose published volumes include ''Break the Mirror'' (Blackberry, 1996) and ''Let's Eat Stars'' (Blackberry, 1997).

Mr. Gwertzman, 27, is an owner of Escape Factory, a new company developing video games in Seattle. He was until last week a marketing manager in Tokyo for Microsoft. He graduated from Harvard. His father is the editor of The New York Times on the Web and was the foreign editor of The Times from 1989 to 1995. The bridegroom's mother is a coordinator of the religious education program at St. Gabriel's Roman Catholic Church in Riverdale.
